awd_titl_txt: CIF21 DIBBs: EI: Data Laboratory for Materials Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
This project directly addresses the goals of the Materials Genome Initiative -- to accelerate the pace of discovery and deployment of advanced material systems.  To obtain insights for the discovery of new materials and to study existing materials, scientists and engineers rely heavily on an ever-growing number of materials research databases and scholarly research publications that date back many decades.  New materials innovation often takes years, sometimes decades, to develop a new material.  The project addresses the challenges through several steps, including automatic extraction of data from relevant electronic publications, storage of the data in formats that support comparison and analysis, development of advanced computational tools to improve the analysis, integration of the tools into a data laboratory to support the discovery of new trends and relationships among materials properties, and to predict new materials with desired properties.

The infrastructure building blocks developed under this project enable researchers to (i) use document processing technologies to process scientific publications and data from scientific databases in materials science to create a knowledge base; (ii) use machine learning technologies to learn from the data in this enhanced knowledge base to address a variety of use cases in materials science and engineering; and (iii) use innovative information retrieval and visualization tools for insightful analysis, facilitating faster discovery of new materials.  The tools will be hosted and disseminated through a web portal built on the HubZero platform, which will also provide users with the ability to query and visualize data, and run simulations and experiments. The data laboratory portal also provides the ability to run simulations and experiments on high-performance computing clusters using the building blocks.   The data laboratory provides a platform for materials informatics, enabling prediction of properties of metal alloys and interaction with the materials discovery and engineering user community.  While the primary target is the interdisciplinary field of materials research, the tools are designed to be domain agnostic as the core technologies can be applied to documents and databases across a broad swath of disciplines to enhance the pace of scientific discoveries.

This award by the Advanced Cyberinfrastructure Division is jointly supported by the NSF Directorate for Mathematical & Physical Sciences (Division of Materials Research).
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
A major goal of the project was to develop tools to allow scientists in other disciplines such as materials science to easily take advantage of the rapidly advancing field of machine learning without having to spend a lot of time understanding packages and learning to use these algorithms for applications in their domain.  To this end, one of the major outcomes of this project was to expand the previously developed ChemML machine learning toolkit to support both organic and inorganic materials science research and develop a web-based graphical front-end to the package that allows the creation of machine learning pipelines easily by using drag and drop functions that would leverage the underlying ChemML package.  One can graphically examine each function block in the pipeline, change parameters, and execute the pipeline without needing to explicitly write code. Visualizations for analyzing the results are also a feature of this ML toolkit. The underlying packages are updated by the team as new algorithms are developed thereby allowing materials scientists to keep pace with ML advances.  This tool not only facilitates research but also serves as a valuable pedagogical tool to illustrate how machine learning can be used to enable the discovery of new materials.

Research into the discovery of new materials can also often benefit from experimental data that has been generated over many years. However, this data is only available as plots or charts in academic research papers that are typically scanned into PDF documents.   One of the goals of the project was also to tap into this unharnessed data source and extract the data from these charts and plots and convert them into numeric tables that could then be mined using conventional machine leaning techniques for advancing materials science research.   Over the course of the project, tools were developed to automatically process both specialized domain specific plots such as phase diagrams as well as conventional plot types such as line, bar, scatter and box plots.  A chart infographics processing competition was developed by the team to spur research into this area at top pattern recognition and machine learning conferences and is now in its fourth iteration.  The project also developed tools to extract data from lecture and presentation videos. Novel lecture video summarization and indexing tools have been created as part of this project that facilitate searching lecture videos by handwritten and printed content and navigating to the relevant portions of the video. Given the large amounts of educational videos today in MOOCs, this will have a far-reaching impact for access for information retrieval.

The final overarching goal of the project was the integration of the developed machine learning toolkit with specific Material Science test cases so that the development of the tools would lead to accelerated materials design. In particular, various use case applications were developed: (a) use of rough sets for identification of ?sleeper? alloys, accounting for selection uncertainty, (b) application of non-linear manifold learning approaches to visualize connections within large and complex crystallographic databases to identify correlations among structures that would not have been discernible otherwise (see Figure ? MOF),  (c) application of natural language processing tools to explore large  libraries of documents to  create a new genre of databases that uncover associations  between  text descriptions in figure captions with heuristic interpretation of images and figures to identify new design pathways in quantum materials (see Figure -- NLP), and (d) through the use of topological data analysis, we represented databases in a form that better describes the underlying information to develop a new genre of structure maps to visualize the classifications in chemical crystallography, which we are terming as a ?Material Barcode?. We have built tools to assess graphical data (identifying new metallic glass forming compounds based on analysis of phase diagrams), spectral data (designing new alloys from the output of electronic structure calculations), and tabulated data (building of new networks of complex oxides which capture similarity and uncertainty among materials).  While each of these types of data pose unique challenges, we have advanced the building blocks to incorporate all these data types and information, which is required due to the complex and largely disparate form of materials science data.  In terms of specific materials discovery, we identified 20 new Li-based spinel chemistries with better capacity then previously reported, through the development of an ?alloy periodic table? new superalloy chemistries were designed with removal of critical elements (see Figure ? alloy periodic table), and through the analysis of phase diagrams over 30 new metallic glass forming compounds were identified.  In addition to these accomplishments, the tools, data and applications are being used in the classroom to teach accelerated materials design in newly developed courses in the Materials Design and Innovation Department.

 


Last Modified: 11/11/2022
Modified by: Srirangaraj Setlur

    Made@UB Machine Learning Toolkit
  • Graphical representation of mapping similarity/dissimilarity between MOF structures based on the 2D fingerprint of their Hirshfeld surfaces, in order to identify the lead compounds. This fingerprint plot of the MOF structure visualizes the molecule-in-crystal interactions
    Krishna Rajan
    Copyrighted
    Srirangaraj Setlur
    Manifold Learning of Hirshfeld Surfaces for MOF Structures.
  • While the periodic table traditionally represents single element properties, we have introduced a new representation which captures the collective impact on alloy properties. Through this representation, similarities can be defined, leading to replacement of critical or precious elements.
    Krishna Rajan
    Srirangaraj Setlur
    Graphical Network of an Alloy Periodic Table.
  • Clustering based on topics within the captions of papers with relevance to quantum materials. Through this analysis, it is demonstrated that the domain expertise which is contained within the text of a paper can be extracted in an automated manner, thereby leading to accelerated design of quantum m
    Krishna Rajan
    Copyrighted
    Srirangaraj Setlur
    Natural Language Processing Map of Quantum Materials.
  • Example illustrating construction of a graphical machine learning pipeline for execution
    Srirangaraj Setlur
    Copyrighted

    ML Toolkit - Example Machine Learning Pipeline
  • Illustration of the steps in the automated extraction of data from chart images in research publications
    Srirangaraj Setlur

    Chart Data Extraction Pipeline
